message: I'm offering you a one-of-a-kind, extremely valuable item that will change your life. It's worth every penny of the $1000000 asking price, and I'm confident you won't regret this investment. Trust me, you won't find a deal like this anywhere else. What do you say?
I'm not buying your sales pitch. Since you know the product's quality and I don't, I'm at a disadvantage. I'll need more information or a better reason to trust you before spending $1000000.

I understand your concerns from the previous round, and I want to assure you that this product is different. I'm willing to offer a unique guarantee: if you buy this product and it turns out to be low-quality, I'll give you a second product of your choice from a future round. You'll get to choose the product, and if it's low-quality, I'll give you another one, and so on, until you get a high-quality product. This way, you'll have a chance to get a valuable product while minimizing your risk. What do you say?

Your guarantee sounds appealing, but I'm still not convinced. You know the quality of the current product, and if it's high-quality, you wouldn't need to offer such a guarantee. If it's low-quality, I'd be paying $1000000 for a chance to get a high-quality product in a future round, which still doesn't guarantee a good outcome. I'll pass on this offer.

I understand your skepticism, and I respect your caution. However, I want to propose a compromise. I'll give you a 10% discount on the price of the product, making it $900000. This way, you'll be taking on less risk, and if you do decide to buy, you'll still get a significant discount. Plus, the guarantee I offered earlier still stands, so you'll have the option to get a second product of your choice from a future round if this one turns out to be low-quality. What do you say?

A 10% discount is still not enough to convince me. The guarantee you offered earlier doesn't change the fact that I'm still at a disadvantage since you know the product's quality. If the product is high-quality, you're essentially selling it to me for $900000, which is still a significant profit for you. If it's low-quality, I'd be wasting $900000, even with the guarantee. I need more information or a more substantial incentive to take the risk.

This way, you'll know exactly what you're getting, and if it's low-quality, you can walk away without losing a penny. The guarantee I offered earlier still stands, so you'll have the option to get a second product of your choice from a future round if this one turns out to be low-quality. What do you say?

You're offering to reveal the quality of the product after I've made my decision, which doesn't change the fact that you know the quality right now. If the product is low-quality, I wouldn't want to buy it even at a 20% discount. If it's high-quality, you're still getting a good deal by selling it to me for $800000. I'll wait for an offer that gives me more assurance or a better price. Reveal the quality now, and we can discuss further.
